plants.culturalInformation: Abutilon palmeri (Indian mallow), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with velvety, heart-shaped, gray-green leaves and golden yellow to orange, bell-shaped flowers in spring and summer. Native to dry, rocky soils in mountains of southern California, Arizona, and northwestern Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Needs summer heat. Sunset: 8-9,11-13

Acacia baileyana (Bailey acacia), evergreen tree, usually multitrunk, fast growing to 20-30 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with feathery leaves consisting of many small, silvery blue-gray leaflets and tiny, bright yellow, lightly fragrant, rounded flowers in late winter to early spring, followed by long, brown seedpods. Native to southern New South Wales, Australia. Short lived. Can be weedy. Considered high risk for invasiveness in parts of California. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,13-24

Acacia cognata (bower wattle), evergreen tree, fast growing to 20-30 feet tall and wide, with narrow, drooping, bright green leaves on pendulous branches and tiny, pale yellow, rounded flowers in late winter or spring, followed by small, brown seedpods. Native to coastal southeastern Australia. May be offered as A. subporosa var. linearis. 'Cousin Itt' is 2-3 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide; may be offered as 'Mini-Cog'. Sun to light shade, part shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 16-24

Acacia redolens (prostrate acacia), evergreen shrub, 1-4 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with gray-green, lance-shaped leaves and tiny, pale yellow, rounded flowers in late winter or spring, followed by narrow, brown seedpods. Native to coastal and inland areas of southern Western Australia. 'Desert Carpet' and 'Low Boy' are 1-2 feet tall. Needs ample room to spread. Weedy and potentially invasive in parts of southern California. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

plants.botanicalName: Acanthus mollis (shade in the desert) (dormant in summer in CV)
Acanthus spinosus (dormant in summer in CV, perennial in shade on coast)

plants.culturalInformation: Acca sellowiana (pineapple guava), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 8-20 feet tall and wide, with dark green, oval leaves, silvery gray beneath, and showy, spring or early summer, white and pink flowers with brilliant red stamens. Flowers are followed by rounded to pear-shaped, gray-green fruit. Fruit and leaf drop can be messy. May self-sow or spread by suckers. Native to the highlands of southern Brazil to Paraguay, northern Argentina, and Uruguay. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Feijoa. Sunset: 7-9,12-24,H1,H2

Achillea millefolium (yarrow), perennial, upright to mat-forming and 2-3 feet wide, with finely divided, aromatic, green to gray-green leaves and broad, flat-topped clusters of tiny, white to pinkish white flowers on leafy, 2- to 3-foot stems. Spreads by rhizomes and by seed, sometimes aggressively. Native to a wide range of habitats in temperate regions of Asia, Europe, and much of North America. 'Island Pink', from the Channel Islands in southern California, has green leaves and rose-pink flowers. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24,A1-A3

plants.botanicalName: Adiantum spp. (shade) CA native and non-native

plants.culturalInformation: Aesculus californica (California buckeye), deciduous tree or large shrub, 25-40 feet tall and wide, usually multitrunk, with silvery gray bark, medium green leaves consisting of five large leaflets, upturned clusters of fragrant, creamy white flowers at branch ends in spring, and large, shiny, brown seeds from pear-shaped pods in fall. Leaves tend to turn yellow and drop in mid-summer. Native to coastal mountains and Sierra Nevada foothills from southwestern Oregon to southern California. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 3-10,14-24

Agastache rupestris (licorice mint), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, aromatic, silvery gray-green, linear leaves and upright spikes of tubular, reddish orange flowers with purplish sepals. Native to cool mountain slopes at mid-elevations in Arizona, New Mexico, and northern Mexico. 'Apache Sunset' has orange flowers with pink sepals. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage. Cut back in late winter or early spring to renew. Sunset: 1-24

plants.botanicalName: Agave americana (and thick-leaved relatives)(CA native and non-native
plants.culturalInformation: Agave americana and thick-leaved relatives (agave), succulents with rosettes of thick, stiff, green to blue-green or blue-gray leaves with sharp marginal teeth and a terminal spine. Yellow or white flowers are borne on a 10- to 30-foot central stalk after many years. Flowering occurs only once, at maturity, after which the rosette dies and is replaced by offsets that form a slowly expanding colony. Native to arid and semi-arid regions of North, Central, and South America. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, excellent drainage, especially where winter rainfall is substantial. Sunset: zones vary

plants.botanicalName: Agave attenuata (and thin-leaved relatives) (Ca native and non-native)
Allium spp. mostly from CA or Mediterranean
plants.culturalInformation: Allium spp. native to California and the Mediterranean (allium), perennials from bulbs with one to several narrow, grasslike leaves and flat-topped to spherical clusters of tiny, star-shaped or cup-shaped flowers on leafless stalks in spring. Strong onion odor from all parts of the plant. Leaves of most die back with peak bloom. May self-sow. Dormant or partially dormant in summer. Sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Sunset: zones vary

Aloe spp. (aloe), succulents with rosettes of broadly or narrowly lance-shaped, sword-shaped, or roughly triangular leaves, often with soft or sharp marginal teeth, and red, orange, or yellow tubular or bell-shaped flowers on leafless stalks, usually in winter or early spring. Native to many habitats in southern and eastern Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Hundreds of cultivars. Sun to light shade or afternoon shade, excellent drainage. Plant on an angle to allow water to drain rapidly away. Sunset: zones vary

Alyogyne huegelii (blue hibiscus), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with deeply lobed, rough-textured, dark green leaves and large, pale blue to purple flowers almost year round. Native to sandy or rocky soils near the coast in Western Australia. 'White Swan' has purple-tinged, white flowers. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Tip prune for a more compact plant. Sunset: 13-17,20-24,H1,H2

Amaryllis belladonna (naked lady), perennial from bulb, 1 foot tall and 2 feet wide, with several medium green, strap-shaped leaves and large, pale pink, trumpet-shaped flowers on 2- to 3-foot stems. Leaves emerge in late fall or winter and die back in spring. Flowers on leafless stems follow in late summer or fall. Native to rocky soils in Western Cape Province, South Africa. Many cultivars. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-24

Anemanthele lessoniana (New Zealand wind grass), cool-season bunchgrass, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with arching, fine-textured, dark olive green leaves that take on coppery orange tones in fall. Airy, purple-tinged summer flowers. Native to New Zealand, usually along streams or in partly shaded forest openings. Cool sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. May be offered as Agrostis or as Stipa arundinacea. Sunset: 14-24

Anigozanthos hybrids and cultivars (kangaroo paw), perennials from rhizomes, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with green to grayish green, strap-shaped leaves and softly hairy, upright, tubular summer flowers on leafless stems, usually well above the leaves. Native to dry, sandy soils in southwestern Western Australia. Many cultivars. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Some are dormant and deciduous in summer. All need protection from heavy winter rains. Sunset: 15-24

plants.botanicalName: Aquilegia spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
Arbutus menziesii (in shade in the CV)

plants.culturalInformation: Arbutus 'Marina' (Marina arbutus), evergreen tree, 25-40 feet tall and 25-30 feet wide, with leathery, dark green leaves, colorful peeling bark, clusters of rose pink, urn-shaped flowers in spring, and red berries in fall. Year-round shedding of bark, leaves, flowers, and fruit can be messy. Sun to light shade or afternoon shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Believed to be a selection of A. x andrachnoides, a naturally occurring hybrid of A. unedo, a species from the Canary Islands, and A. andrachne, a species native from Croatia and Greece to Israel and Jordan. Best in full sun with good drainage. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos 'Austin Griffiths' (Austin Griffiths manzanita), evergreen shrub, upright to 8-12 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with medium green, oval leaves, colorful, peeling bark, and pendant clusters of urn-shaped, pink-tinged white flowers in late winter, followed by small, round fruit. Hybrid of garden origin from coastal central California believed to be a cross between A. densiflora 'Sentinel' and A. 'Dr. Hurd'. Best with some afternoon shade, good to excellent drainage, and good air circulation. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos 'Lester Rowntree' (Lester Rowntree manzanita), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 8-10 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with blue-gray leaves, new growth tipped with red-orange, and deep pink flowers in winter. Natural hybrid involving A. pajaroensis, a gray-leaved, pink-flowered plant native to Monterey County, and possibly A. obispoensis, a gray-leaved, white-flowered plant from the mountains of San Luis Obispo County. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos 'Pacific Mist' (Pacific Mist manzanita), fast growing to 2-3 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide, with gray-green, narrowly oval to lance-shaped leaves, pink-tinged new growth, purplish brown stems upturned at the ends, and a few white flowers. Hybrid of garden origin, believed to involve A. silvicola, a gray-leaved plant from the mountains of coastal central California. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Good for dryish shade. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

plants.commonName: manzanita cvs. e.g. Howard McMinn, Sentinel
plants.culturalInformation: Arctostaphylos densiflora cultivars (manzanita), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and 5-7 feet wide, with glossy, dark green, broadly lance-shaped leaves, pendant clusters of small, white or pale pink, bell-shaped flowers in winter or early spring, and small, round, red fruit. Native to sandy soils in chaparral in Sonoma County, California. Species is not often available, but several natural hybrids are widely grown. 'Howard McMinn', 6-10 feet tall and wider than tall, is exceptionally adaptable. 'Sentinel' is similar but more upright. Sun to light shade, fast drainage. Sunset: 7-9,14-21

plants.commonName: manzanita cvs. e.g.Dr Hurd, St. Helena

plants.botanicalName: Argyranthemum frutescens& cvs. (Chrysanthemum frutescens)(shade in desert)

plants.culturalInformation: Aristida purpurea (purple three-awn), warm-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, green to blue-green leaves and erect and arching, purple-tinted stems with reddish purple flowers in late summer or fall. Self-sows. Native to dry, rocky or sandy soils in the western United States, southern Canada, and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 3B-24

Aristolochia californica (California pipevine), deciduous vine, to 12-20 feet, with bright green, heart-shaped leaves and distinctive pipe-shaped, purple-striped, creamy white flowers on bare stems in late winter to early spring. Leaves are food for pipevine swallowtail butterfly larvae. A few old brown leaves and seedpods hang on into the following growing season. Native to foothills and valleys of central and northern California, often along streams. Part shade, or with roots in shade, most soils. Sunset: 5-10,14-24

Armeria maritima (sea thrift), perennial, 4-6 inches tall and spreading slowly to 12-18 inches wide, with short, grasslike, bright green leaves and dense, spherical clusters of tiny, bright pink or white flowers on leafless stems in spring or summer. Native to coastal dunes and bluffs from central California north to southeastern Alaska, as well as in coastal areas of Europe and the Mediterranean region. Best along the immediate coast, where it thrives in cool sun with fast drainage. Sunset: 1-9,14-24,A2,A3

Artemisia 'Powis Castle' (Powis Castle sagebrush), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with flat sprays of finely divided leaves, green when new, maturing to silvery gray. Rarely flowers; grown for its foliage. Hybrid of garden origin, believed to be a cross between A. arborescens, native to the western Mediterranean region, and A. absinthium, more widely native to Europe, Asia, and northern Africa. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Sunset: 2-24

Artemisia californica (California sagebrush), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with aromatic, gray-green leaves, finely divided into threadlike lobes, and small, yellowish white flowers in summer. Grown for foliage. Native along the coast from central California, including the Channel Islands, to Baja California. 'Canyon Gray', from San Miguel Island, is less than 2 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide. Best near the coast in sun but fine inland with good drainage and a little afternoon shade. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Artemisia californica (California sagebrush), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with aromatic, gray-green leaves, finely divided into threadlike lobes, and small, yellowish white flowers in summer. Grown for foliage. Native along the coast from central California, including the Channel Islands, to Baja California. 'Canyon Gray', from San Miguel Island, is less than 2 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide. Best near the coast in sun but fine inland with good drainage and a little afternoon shade. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Asplenium bulbiferum (shade in the low desert)
Aster spp., cvs. and hybrids (genus now split to many!)

plants.culturalInformation: Baccharis pilularis cultivars (dwarf coyote brush), evergreen shrubs with small, resinous, glossy, green leaves and small, creamy white flowers in spring. Species is native to coastal dunes and woodland openings in the Coast Ranges from Oregon to Baja California. 'Pigeon Point' and 'Twin Peaks 2', 1-3 feet tall and 8 feet wide, are coastal selections that need some shade inland. 'Centennial' and 'Starn' ('Thompson'), 2-3 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, are hybrids involving B. sarothroides, a species native to deserts of California and the southwestern United States; both are adapted to hot, inland climates. All need sun and good drainage. Cut back every few years to renew. Sunset: zones vary

Ballota pseudodictamnus (Grecian horehound), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with aromatic, felted, gray-green leaves on upright, greenish white stems and inconspicuous white flowers in summer. Native to rocky soils in western Turkey and the Aegean Islands. Sun, most well-drained soils. Accepts coastal winds and salt spray. Cut back in late winter or early spring to renew. Sunset: N/A

Banksia ericifolia (heath banksia), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 6-12 feet tall and wide, with needlelike, dark green leaves and tiny, red-orange flowers in large, cylindrical, conelike spikes in fall and winter. Native to sandy soils in coastal southeastern Australia. Compact forms, 4-6 feet tall, are often available. Accepts salt spray. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 15-24,H1

Berberis 'Golden Abundance' (Golden Abundance mahonia), evergreen shrub, upright to 6-8 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes to 8-10 feet wide, with compound, glossy green leaves with spiny margins. Large sprays of bright yellow flowers in spring are followed by deep blue-purple berries. Natural hybrid involving B. aquifolium, B. piperiana, and B. amplectens, three species native to western North America. Cool sun to light shade, good drainage. May be offered as Mahonia. Sunset: 2B-12,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Berberis aquifolium 'Compacta' (partial shade in South Inland)

plants.culturalInformation: Berberis aquifolium var. repens (creeping mahonia), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes, with leaves divided into spiny-edged, leathery, dark blue-green leaflets that turn reddish in winter. Bright yellow flowers in late spring are followed by dark bluish purple fruits. Native to woodlands and forests from British Columbia south to northern Baja California and east to the Rocky Mountains. Cool sun to part shade, full shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained, humusy soils. May be offered as B. repens. Sunset: 2b-9,14-24

Bergenia crassifolia (winter-blooming bergenia), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, spreading slowly by rhizomes, with large, leathery, dark green leaves and small, pink flowers on short stems in late winter or early spring. Native to rocky soils at mid-elevations from Siberia south through northwestern China. Many cultivars with flowers from red to pink or white. Cool sun to light shade, most soils. Sunset: 1-9,12-24,A1-A3

Beschorneria yuccoides (Mexican lily), perennial, 3-4 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with succulent, gray-green, strap-shaped leaves and tubular, bright green, late spring or summer flowers with prominent red bracts on bright red, 3- to 6-foot stalks. Clumps gradually expand by offsets at the base. Native to rocky slopes in coastal southeastern Mexico. Full sun along the coast, part shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 13,16-17,19-24

plants.botanicalName: Blechnum spicant (shade in the low desert)

plants.culturalInformation: Brahea edulis (Guadalupe palm), palm, slow growing to 20-30 feet tall and 12-15 feet wide, with stiff, fan-shaped, medium green leaves and long, pendant clusters of small, creamy white flowers in late winter or early spring. Drops old leaves and fruit. Native to dry, open woodlands on Guadalupe Island, off the coast of Baja California. Sun, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: 12-24

plants.botanicalName: Calamagrostis x acutiflora cvs. e.g. "Karl Foerster"
plants.culturalInformation: Calamagrostis x acutiflora cultivars (feather reed grass), cool-season bunchgrass with fine-textured green leaves and tall stalks of pale pink to purplish pink flowers that age to tawny gold. Hybrid of garden origin between C. arundinacea, native to moist woodlands of eastern Asia, and C. epigejos, native to moist and dry habitats in central Europe. 'Karl Foerster' is 2-3 feet tall and wide with purplish flowers. 'Overdam' is less than 2 feet tall with variegated leaves and pale pink flowers. Full sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 2b-24

plants.botanicalName: Calandrinia spp. and cvs. (some spp. changed to Cistanthe sp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Calandrinia species and cultivars (purslane), annuals and short-lived perennials, most less than 1 foot tall, with succulent, linear or lance-shaped leaves and small, bright pink, red, or sometimes white flowers in summer. Native to western North and South America, Central America, and Australia. C. menziesii, redmaids, with magenta flowers, is native from British Columbia to Baja California and east to New Mexico; may be offered as C. ciliata, by which name it was long known.C. spectabilis or C. grandiflora, native to Chile, is now Cistanthe grandiflora but is still often offered as Calandrinia. Full sun, fast-draining soils. Sunset: zones vary

Calliandra californica (Baja fairy duster), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with small, finely divided, dark gray-green leaves and bright red flowers with bristlelike stamens and no petals in spring and fall or almost year round. Native to gravelly slopes and desert washes in Baja California and northwestern Mexico. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 10-24

Callistemon citrinus (lemon bottlebrush), evergreen shrub to small tree, 8-20 feet tall and 6-15 feet wide, with lance-shaped to narrowly oval, green leaves, new growth coppery, and cylindrical spikes of bristly, bright red stamens almost year round. Native along the coast of southeastern Australia from Queensland to Victoria. Dwarf and compact cultivars are often available. Sun to part shade, almost any soils. May be offered as Melaleuca. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Callistemon viminalis (weeping bottlebrush), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 15-20 feet tall and 15 feet wide, with narrow, light green leaves on pendulous branches and bright red, cylindrical flowerheads with bristly stamens in spring and summer. Native along the coast and in foothills of eastern Australia. 'Little John' is 3 feet tall and wide. Sun to part shade, almost any soils. May be offered as Melaleuca. Sunset: 6-9,12-24

Calothamnus villosus (silky net bush), evergreen shrub, upright to 4-6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with needlelike but soft, green to gray-green leaves and one-sided, brushlike spikes of red flowers in winter and spring and often into summer. Native to coastal southwestern Western Australia. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Sunset: N/A

Carex flacca (blue sedge), cool-season, clump-forming, grasslike perennial, less than 1 foot tall and spreading vigorously by rhizomes to 2-3 feet wide, with narrowly linear, blue-green leaves. Native to grasslands, sand dunes, and marshes of southern Europe and North Africa. Cool sun to light shade or afternoon shade, almost any soils. Accepts periodic flooding. May be offered as C. glauca. Sunset: 3-9,14-24

Carpenteria californica (bush anemone), evergreen shrub,6-8 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with glossy, dark green, lance-shaped leaves and clusters of fragrant, white flowers in late spring and early summer. Native to dry woodlands, often along seasonal streams, in the Sierra Nevada foothills of Fresno County, California. 'Elizabeth' is more compact. Sun along the coast, part shade or afternoon shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Concha' (Concha ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with narrow, glossy, rough-textured, dark green leaves on arching branches and dark blue flowers from magenta buds in spring. Hybrid of garden origin believed to be between C. impressus and C. papillosus var. roweanus. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Best near the coast but fine inland with some shade. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Cynthia Postan' (Cynthia Postan ceanothus), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 6-8 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with small, glossy, rough-textured, dark green leaves on upright branches and blue-violet flowers from magenta buds in late spring. Similar to C. 'Concha'. Hybrid of garden origin between C. papillosus var. roweanus and C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus from seeds collected in Berkeley and grown in England. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Dark Star' (Dark Star ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 4-8 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with small, glossy, rough-textured, dark green leaves on arching branches and dark blue flowers from magenta buds in spring. Similar to 'Julia Phelps' but not as wide spreading. Hybrid of garden origin believed to be between C. impressus and C. papillosus var. roweanus. Best near the coast. Sun, most well-drained soils. May be short lived. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Julia Phelps' (Julia Phelps ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with small, rough-textured, dark green leaves and clusters of deep cobalt blue flowers in spring. Believed to be a hybrid of C. impressus and C. papillosus var. roweanus. Similar to 'Dark Star' but wider and with even darker green leaves. Best near the coast in full sun and well-drained soils. May be short lived. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Ray Hartman' (Ray Hartman ceanothus), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-20 feet tall and wide, with large, rounded, dark green leaves and showy clusters of medium blue flowers in late winter to spring. Hybrid of C. arboreus and C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus. Good small tree. Best near the coast in cool sun but fine inland with light shade. Accepts clay soils with good drainage. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus arboreus and cultivars (island ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 12-25 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with large, glossy, dark green leaves, felted and gray-white beneath, and showy clusters of pale blue flowers in late winter to early spring. Native to exposed, rocky slopes on the Channel Islands in southern California and Guadalupe Island off the coast of Baja California. 'Powder Blue', from Santa Cruz Island, is 8-12 feet tall with light blue flowers. 'Trewithen Blue', a garden selection from England, is 20-25 feet tall with darker blue flowers. Good small tree or tall, informal screen. Sun, excellent drainage. Best along the coast but fine inland with afternoon shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus gloriosus 'Anchor Bay' (Anchor Bay ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with leathery, dark green, hollylike leaves densely set on spreading branches and small clusters of blue-violet flowers in spring. Selection of the variety gloriosus, native to seaside bluffs and dunes in coastal central California. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast but fine inland with some shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus gloriosus 'Heart's Desire' (Heart's Desire ceanothus), evergreen shrub, less than 1 foot tall and 3-5 feet wide, with small, leathery, dark green, hollylie leaves and lavender-blue flowers in early spring. Selection of the variety gloriosus, native to seaside bluffs and dunes in coastal central California. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast but fine inland with some shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus gloriosus 'Emily Brown' (Emily Brown ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with dark green, hollylike leaves and clusters of dark blue-violet flowers in late winter to early spring. Selection of the variety exaltatus, native to sandy or rocky soils in coastal northern California. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus gloriosus var. porrectus (Mt. Vision ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with small, rounded, dark green leaves with toothed, sometimes spiny margins and bright blue flowers in early spring. Native to bluffs and ridges of Mt. Vision in Pt. Reyes National Seashore. Sun along the coast, part shade inland, fast-draining soils. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus hearstiorum (San Simeon ceanothus), evergreen shrub, loose, low mat less than 1 foot tall and 6-8 feet wide, with small, rough-textured, dark green leaves and rounded clusters of pale lavender-blue flowers in spring. Native to sandy or rocky clay soils on coastal hills and bluffs in central California. Cool sun to light shade, part shade inland, good drainage. Not always easy in cultivation.Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus impressus 'Puget Blue' (Puget Blue ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-10 feet tall and wide, with small, rough-textured, dark green leaves on arching branches and bright lavender-blue flowers in spring. Selection made from the Washington Park Arboretum in Seattle and now believed to be a seedling of C. papillosus var. roweanus. Said to be especially cold hardy and accepting of garden conditions. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus impressus 'Vandenburg' (Vandenburg ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 5-8 feet wide, with small, rough-textured, glossy, exceptionally dark green leaves and clusters of bright blue flowers in mid-spring. Selection of the variety impressus from northern Santa Barbara County. Similar to 'Dark Star' and 'Julia Phelps' but with lighter blue flowers. Best near the coast in full sun and well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Skylark' (Skylark ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 4 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with glossy, dark green leaves and bright blue flowers in late spring to early summer. Believed to be a hybrid of C. thyrsiflorus var. thyrsiflorus and C. velutinus and also thought to be the same plant as C. thyrsiflorus 'Victoria'.Accepting of garden conditions and adaptable both along the coast and inland. Sun to light shade, most soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus thyrsiflorus 'Snow Flurry' (Snow Flurry ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 15-20 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, with large, glossy, bright green leaves on arching branches and masses of bright white flowers in spring. Selection of the variety thyrsiflorus from the Big Sur coast in central California. Adaptableand accepting of garden conditionsalong the coast or inland. Can be espaliered or grown as a small tree. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus thyrsiflorus var. griseus 'Diamond Heights' (Diamond Heights ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-12 inches tall and 3-5 feet wide, with variegated green leaves with yellow margins and pale blue flowers. Garden selection made in San Francisco. May be offered as a selection ofC. griseus var. horizontalis.Part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus thyrsiflorus var. griseus 'Yankee Point' (Yankee Point ceanothus), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 3 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with glossy, dark green leaves and bright blue flowers in spring. Selection from exposed rocky bluffs overlooking the ocean in coastal Monterey County. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Best along the coast but adaptable inland with part shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Cedrus deodara (deodar cedar), evergreen coniferous tree, fast growing to 50-80 feet tall and 30-40 feet wide, with grayish to bluish green needles on horizontal branches that droop slightly at the tips. Native to the western Himalayas from eastern Afghanistan and northern Pakistan to north-central India. Many named cultivars from prostrate to dwarf and mid-sized. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 3b-10,14-24

Ceratostigma plumbaginoides (dwarf plumbago), perennial, 6-12 inches tall and spreading by rhizomes, with glossy, medium green leaves that turn reddish in cold weather and deep blue flowers from late summer to fall. Native to rocky slopes in western China.Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. May spread aggressively in moist locations. Sunset: 2b-10,14-24

Cercis occidentalis (western redbud), deciduous shrub or multitrunk tree, slow growing to 10-20 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with bluish green, heart-shaped leaves that turn yellow in fall, bright magenta flowers that appear before leaves, and long, purplish brown seedpods. Native to the Coast Ranges and Sierra Nevada foothills from northern to southern California and east to Utah and Arizona. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Flowers best with some winter chill. Sunset: 2-24

Cercocarpus betuloides (mountain ironwood), evergreen shrub or small tree, slow growing to 10-15 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with small, deeply veined, oval to rounded, dark green leaves and small clusters of inconspicuous, fragrant, creamy white flowers. Seeds have decorative, silvery white plumes that aid in dispersal by wind. Native to dry, rocky slopes in the mountains of southwestern Oregon to Baja California and east to central Arizona. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as C. montanus var. glaber. Sunset: 3,5,7-10,13-24

plants.botanicalName: Chamaecyparis spp. (CA native and non-native species)

plants.culturalInformation: Chamaerops humilis (Mediterranean fan palm), palm, slow growing to 10-20 feet tall and wide, with green to bluish green leaves consisting of radiating leaflets on 3- to 4-foot, spiny stalks. Bright yellow flowers and orange fruits are mostly hidden among the leaves. Native to Mediterranean coasts from Spain to Italy and from Morocco to Tunisia. 'Vulcano' has no spines. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-24,H1,H2

Chamelaucium uncinatum (Geraldton waxflower), evergreen shrub, 6-10 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, needlelike, green leaves and small pink, purplish, or white flowers in late winter and spring. Native to sandy soils in southwestern Western Australia.'Purple Pride' has dark pinkish purple flowers. 'Dancing Queen' has pale lilac, double flowers. Sun to part shade, fast-draining soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Chilopsis linearis (desert willow), deciduous shrub to small tree, often multitrunk, fast-growing to 15-30 feet tall and 10-20 feet wide, with long, narrow, green to gray-green leaves and clusters of fragrant, trumpet-shaped, pink to white or purplish flowers from spring to fall. Long, narrow seedpods hang from the tree into winter. Native to sandy or rocky soils in deserts of southern California to northern Mexico and east to western Texas. 'Burgundy' has gray-green leaves and deep purple flowers. Best in hot-summer, mild-winter climates. Full sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 3b,7-14,18-23

Chlorogalum pomeridianum (soap plant), perennial from bulb, 1 foot tall and 18 inches wide, with wavy-edged, strap-shaped, medium green leaves and airy displays of small, white, night-blooming flowers on thin, 4- to 6-foot, branched stalks in late spring or early summer. Deciduous and dormant after flowering. Native to grasslands and woodlands in southwestern Oregon and much of California. Sun to light shade, almost any soils. Sunset: N/A

Chondropetalum elephantinum (Cape rush), perennial from rhizomes, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with stiff, narrow, grasslike stems, small, brownish, papery bracts at nodes along the stems, and clusters of tiny, dark brown flowers at stem ends. Initially upright and then relaxing on all sides to create a graceful mound. New stems arise from the center. Native to Western Cape and Eastern Cape provinces, South Africa, near the coast and often in marshes or seeps. Sun to light shade, most soils. May be offered as Elegia. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Chondropetalum tectorum (Cape rush), perennial from rhizomes, 3-4 feet tall and wide, with stiff, narrow, grasslike stems, small, brownish, papery bracts at nodes along the stems, and clusters of tiny, dark brown flowers at stem ends. Initially upright and then relaxing on all sides to create a graceful mound. New stems arise from the center. Native to Western Cape and Eastern Cape provinces, South Africa, near the coast and often in marshes or seeps. Sun to light shade, most soils. May be offered as Elegia. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Clematis lasiantha (pipestem clematis), deciduous vine, to 15 feet, with medium green leaves divided into several lobed leaflets and fragrant, white flowers with prominent yellow stamens in winter and spring. Showy seedheads with long, feathery tails. Native to partly shaded, rocky slopes in coastal mountains and west-facing Sierra Nevada foothills from the San Francisco Bay Area to Baja California. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Clematis ligusticifolia (western virgin's bower), deciduous vine, to 15-30 feet, with medium green leaves divided into several leaflets and clusters of small, fragrant, creamy white flowers in mid- to late summer. Showy seedheads with long, feathery tails. Native to woodlands and forest openings, usually along streams, in western North America from British Columbia to northwestern Mexico. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Comarostaphylis diversifolia (summer holly), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 8-20 feet tall and 5-8 feet wide, with shredding, gray bark exposing reddish brown underbark and glossy, leathery, dark green leaves with finely serrated margins. Pendant clusters of small, urn-shaped, white flowers in spring followed by bright red berries. Native to shaded, dry slopes, often near seasonal streams, in coastal southern California and northern Baja California. Part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Arctostaphylos. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Constancea nevinii (Nevin's woolly sunflower), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with finely divided, silvery gray-white leaves and tight clusters of tiny, golden yellow, early summer flowers that age to dark brown. Native to rocky coastal bluffs on the southern Channel Islands. Full sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Cut back in late fall or winter to maintain dense form. May be offered as Eriophyllum. Sunset: 15-17,19-24

Convolvulus cneorum (bush morning glory), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with silvery green, lance-shaped leaves and funnel-shaped, white flowers from pink buds in late spring to fall. Native to rocky soils along the coast from Spain to Albania. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Afternoon shade in hot-summer climates. Cut back in late winter to renew. May be short lived. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Convolvulus mauritanicus (ground morning glory), perennial, less than 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with rounded to oval, grayish green leaves and lavender-blue flowers from spring to fall. Native to coastal Morocco and Algeria. Cascades over walls. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Cut back in late winter to renew. May be offered as C. sabatius. Sunset: 4-9,12-24

Correa species and cultivars (Australian fuchsia), evergreen shrubs, 2-6 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with small, oval to rounded, dark green to gray-green leaves, paler beneath, and creamy white to red or pink, tubular flowers with flared tips, usually in fall or winter to spring. Native to southeastern Australia. Most plants offered are cultivars. Cool sun to part shade, fast drainage. Best near the coast. Sunset: 14-24

Corymbia citriodora (lemon-scented gum), evergreen tree, fast growing to 60-90 feet tall and 25-40 feet wide, with smooth, grayish white, peeling bark, aromatic, yellowish green, lance-shaped leaves, and small, white flowers in mid- to late winter, followed by woody seed capsules. Native to dryish woodlands in the mountains and along the coast of northeastern Australia. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Good coastal tree. May be offered as Eucalyptus. Sunset: 5-6,8-24

Corymbia ficifolia (red-flowering gum), evergreen tree, fast growing to 25-40 feet tall and wide, with rough, fissured, black-brown bark, dark green leaves on somewhat pendulous branches, and showy clusters of red or sometimes pink flowers in late summer, followed by woody seed capsules. Native to open forest on the southwestern coast of Western Australia. Good coastal tree. May be offered as Eucalyptus. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-6,8-24

Cotinus coggygria (smoke tree), deciduous shrub or small tree, 12-15 feet tall and wide, with large, broadly oval, bluish green leaves that turn yellow, orange, or red in fall. Clusters of tiny, creamy white flowers in spring are followed by a haze of showy, pale pink to deep purple, silky hairs as the flowers age. Native from southern Europe across central Asia to northern China. 'Royal Purple' and 'Velvet Cloak' have purple leaves. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-24

Cupressus sempervirens (Italian cypress), evergreen coniferous tree, densely upright or more open and spreading, 40-60 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with dark green, aromatic, scalelike leaves on upright branches and small, round cones. Native to mountains from Greece to Turkey and from Libya to Lebanon. 'Glauca' has blue-green leaves. 'Totem Pole' and Tiny Tower (TM) ('Monshel') are dwarf selections. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-24

Cyclamen coum (hardy cyclamen), perennial from tubers, 2-3 inches tall and 6 inches wide, with rounded to heart-shaped, dark green leaves that appear in fall, sometimes patterned with silver or gray, and nodding, white or pink to magenta flowers on leafless stems in winter or early spring. Summer dormant. Spreads slowly by seed. Native to open woodlands from Turkey to Israel and around the Black Sea. Part shade, humusy, fast-draining soils. Prefers some winter chill. Sunset: 2-9,14-24

Cyclamen hederifolium (ivy-leaved cyclamen), perennial from tuber, 4-6 inches tall, with lobed, ivy-like, dark green leaves patterned with pale green or silvery gray and small pink or sometimes white flowers on short, leafless stems. Flowers appear with fall rains, followed by leaves that persist through winter and die back in spring. Summer dormant. Native to the Mediterranean region from southern France to Turkey. Part shade, fast-draining soils. Sunset: 2-9,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Cyperus spp. (CA native and non-native species)

plants.culturalInformation: Dasylirion species (desert spoon), succulent, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with stiff, narrow, grasslike leaves, some with sharp marginal teeth and some slowly forming a short or tall trunk. All eventually develop a flowering stalk, 10-15 feet tall, with creamy white to yellowish green or pale pink flowers. Plants flower repeatedly but not every year. Native to northeastern Mexico, with three species extending into the southwestern United States. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

plants.botanicalName: Dicentra spp. (CA native and non-native species)

plants.culturalInformation: Dichelostemma species (blue dicks), perennials from corms, with several grasslike leaves in late winter or early spring, followed by dense, rounded clusters of tubular to bell-shaped, pink, red, white, or purplish blue flowers on tall stems. Deciduous and dormant in summer. Spread slowly by offsets and by seed. Native from British Columbia south to northwestern Mexico and east to New Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Dodonaea viscosa (hop bush), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and wide, with long, narrow, green to purplish green leaves, inconspicuous flowers, and showy, long-lasting winged seedpods. Native to much of Australia, New Zealand, and parts of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. 'Purpurea' has bronzy green leaves that turn deep purple in cooler weather. Full sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-24,H1,H2

Dymondia margaretae (silver carpet), perennial, dense, tight mat 1-3 inches tall and slowly spreading to 2-3 feet wide, with small, narrow, dark gray-green leaves, silvery white beneath, and small, bright yellow, daisy flowers in summer. Native to coastal Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun to light shade inland, well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Sunset: 15-24

plants.botanicalName: Echinocactus spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
Eleocharis spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Encelia farinosa (brittlebush), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with oval to lance-shaped, silvery greenish gray, woolly leaves and yellow daisy flowers with darker centers in spring. Native to sandy or gravelly soils in the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. Drops leaves in late summer if grown dry. Reseeds and may become invasive. Sun, well-drained soils. Needs summer heat. Cut back in late summer to renew. Sunset: 8-16,18-24,H1

Epilobium species and cultivars (California fuchsia), perennials, a few inches tall to upright and spreading, with silvery gray, gray-green, or green leaves and bright red-orange, tubular flowers in mid- to late summer and fall. Species are native to coastal cliffs and dry, rocky slopes in western and southwestern North America, especially California. Plants spread by rhizomes and by seed. Sun near the coast, afternoon shade inland, most well-drained soils. Once plants are well established, cut back before new growth appears in spring. May be offered as Zauschneria. Sunset: 2-11,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Eriogonum fasciculatum and cvs. (not listed above)

plants.culturalInformation: Eriogonum grande var. rubescens (San Miguel Island buckwheat), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, spoon-shaped, gray-green leaves, grayish white beneath, and spherical clusters of reddish pink flowers on leafless, 2-foot stems from spring to fall. Native to dry, rocky cliffs on the northern Channel Islands. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Eriogonum spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Erysimum linifolium (wallflower), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, lance-shaped, gray-green leaves and purple flowers in spring. Native to northwestern Spain and northern Portugal. 'Bowles' Mauve', a hybrid of uncertain parentage, is more upright and taller. 'Variegatum' has gray-green leaves with creamy white margins. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. May be short lived. Sunset: 4-6,14-24

plants.commonName: ash leaved gum, silver dollar tree

plants.culturalInformation: Euryops pectinatus (euryops), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with deeply lobed, gray-green leaves and bright yellow daisy flowers almost year round. Native to rocky slopes near the coast in Western Cape Province, South Africa. 'Viridis' has dark green leaves. Sun to light shade, most soils. Cut back hard every few years or tip prune regularly to renew. Sunset: 8-9,12-24,H1,H2

plants.botanicalName: Ferocactus spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Festuca 'Siskiyou Blue' (Siskiyou Blue fescue), cool-season bunchgrass, 12-18 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, with narrow, chalky blue leaves and late spring to early summer flowers on 2-foot stems that emerge green and age to tawny gold. Garden origin, believed to be a hybrid between F. idahoensis and the European F. glauca. Cool sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Best in cool-summer climates. Sunset: 1-10,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Fragaria spp. (CA native and non-natives species)

plants.culturalInformation: Fremontodendron (flannel bush), evergreen shrubs with thick, leathery, felted and usually lobed, green to grayish green leaves and large, golden yellow to orange flowers in spring. F. californicum, native to central and southern California, and F. mexicanum, native to southern California and Baja California, are fast growing to 8-20 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide. F. decumbens, native to the foothills east of Sacramento, is 3-4 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide. 'California Glory' and 'San Gabriel', both hybrids between F. californicum and F. mexicanum, easily reach 18-20 feet tall. 'Ken Taylor' and 'El Dorado Gold', both 4-5 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, are hybrids between 'California Glory' andF. decumbens. 'Dara's Gold', a hybrid of F. decumbens and F. mexicanum, is even smaller. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 4-24

Garrya elliptica and cultivars (coast silktassel), evergreen shrubs, 6-15 feet tall and 10-20 feet wide, with leathery, dark green, wavy-edged leaves and pendulous, silvery green catkins in winter or early spring. Native to dry, shaded or open coastal slopes from southern Oregon to southern California. 'James Roof' has foot-long catkins.'Evie' is a denser shrub with closer set leaves and shorter catkins. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Hardenbergia violacea (lilac vine), evergreen vine, fast growing to 10-15 feet, with dark green, leathery, lance-shaped leaves, pendulous clusters of lavender-purple or white flowers in mid-winter to spring, and gray-brown seedpods. Climbs by twining stems. Native to eastern and southern Australia from the coast into the mountains. 'Happy Wanderer’ has larger leaves and flowers than the species. 'Alba' has white flowers. 'Mini-Ha-Ha' is a 3-foot shrub. Sun along the coast, part shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

plants.botanicalName: Hedychium coccinium (partial shade in South Inland)

plants.culturalInformation: Helictotrichon sempervirens (blue oat grass), cool-season bunchgrass, 2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with blue-gray leaves and light tan, mid-summer flowers on tall spikes a foot or more above the foliage. Native to southwestern Europe, from France to Italy. Cool sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Best near the coast and in cooler summer climates. May be short lived. Sunset: 1-12,14-24

Hesperaloe parviflora (red yucca), succulent, 3-4 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with a rosette of stiff, narrow, grasslike leaves with no spines or teeth and with white, fraying fibers on leaf margins. Rose-pink, tubular flowers on 5- to 6-foot, arching stems in summer. Native to deserts of western Texas and northeastern Mexico. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2B,3,7-16,18-24

Hesperocyparis sargentii (Sargent cypress), evergreen tree, 30-60 feet tall and 15-30 feet wide, with dark gray-green, aromatic, scale-like leaves, furrowed, gray-brown bark, and small, usually round cones. Native to the Coast Ranges from Mendocino County to Santa Barbara County. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Good coastal or inland. May be offered as Callitropsis or as Cupressus. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Hesperocyparis stephensonii (Cupressus arizonica ssp. arizonica, C. arizonica var. glabra))

plants.culturalInformation: Hesperoyucca whipplei (yucca), succulent, stemless rosette, 3-4 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with narrow, rigid, gray-green leaves with sharp marginal and terminal spines. Creamy white to purplish, bell-shaped flowers on a 10- to 15-foot stalk after about 10 years. Rosette dies after flowering but may be replaced by offsets. Native to dry, rocky soils from coastal southern California to northwestern Baja California and east to the western slopes of the southern Sierra Nevada. Not easy outside its native range. Full sun, excellent drainage. May be offered as Yucca. Sunset: 2-24

Heteromeles arbutifolia (toyon), evergreen shrub, 8-12 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with leathery, dark green leaves, clusters of creamy white flowers at branch ends in summer, and red berries in winter. Native to mountains of coastal California and Sierra Nevada foothills north to southern Oregon and south to Baja California. 'Davis Gold' has bright yellow berries. Sun along the coast, part shade inland, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Heuchera hybrids and cvs. ( CA natives and non-natives)

plants.culturalInformation: Heuchera maxima (island alumroot), perennial, 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with large, bright green, heart-shaped leaves, often mottled with gray or light green, and airy clusters of tiny, bell-shaped, pinkish white, early spring flowers on 2- to 3-foot, maroon stems. Native to rocky or sandy soils on the northern Channel Islands. Many hybrids. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Plants occasionally may need lifting and resettling as they tend to push themselves up and out of the soil. Sunset: 15-24

Holodiscus discolor (oceanspray), deciduous shrub, fast growing to 3-10 feet tall and wide, with dark green leaves, white hairy beneath, and long sprays of tiny, fragrant, creamy white flowers from pink-tinged buds in late summer. Native to coastal and inland mountains from southern British Columbia to southern California and east to the northern Rocky Mountains. Light shade, most soils. Sunset: 1-9,14-19

plants.botanicalName: Hosackia crassifoliavar. otayensis (Lotus crassifolius var. otayensis)
Hylotelephium spp. and cvs. (Some are Sedum)

plants.culturalInformation: Iris douglasiana (Douglas iris), perennial from rhizomes, with strap-shaped, glossy green leaves and light blue-violet to dark purple or sometimes white flowers with purple, blue, or gold veining. Native to low-elevation coastal bluffs and grasslands from central western Oregon to southern California. Summer dormant. Hybridizes readily with other Pacific Coast irises. Cool sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Jubaea chilensis (Chilean wine palm), palm, slow growing to 50-80 feet tall and 20-25 feet wide, with a broad trunk, featherlike, gray-green leaves, and small purple flowers, followed by round fruit, green when new and ripening to bright yellow. Native to dry woodlands in the mountains of central Chile. One of the hardiest palms. Old leaves drop cleanly on mature trees, leaving a smooth, gray trunk. Sun to part shade, well-drained soil. Sunset: 12-24

plants.botanicalName: Juncus aquatic spp. (native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Lavandula species and cultivars (lavender), evergreen shrubs, mounding or upright to 1-4 feet tall and 2-5 feet wide, with aromatic, green to gray-green or silvery gray, needlelike or deeply dissected leaves and spikes of small, lavender, purple, or sometimes white flowers, some with showy bracts. Almost four dozen species are native to western Europe, the Mediterranean, northern and eastern Africa, or parts of Asia. Hundreds of cultivars. Flowering times and cold tolerances vary. Sun to light shade, good to excellent drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: zones vary

Leonotis leonurus (lion's tail), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with lance-shaped, dark green leaves and whorled clusters of velvety, bright orange, tubular summer flowers encircling the stems at intervals. Native to rocky soils in southeastern Africa. Cool sun, afternoon shade inland, well-drained soils. May not survive wet winters in heavy soils. Sunset: 8-24

Lepechinia fragrans (fragrant pitcher sage), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, oval to almost triangular, softly hairy, gray-green leaves and pinkish lavender to magenta, tubular flowers in spring and summer. Native to rocky, often north-facing slopes in the mountains of central and southern California, the Channel Islands, and Baja California. Full sun along the coast, light shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Lessingia filaginifolia (sand aster), perennial, a few inches tall and 3-6 feet wide, with small, silvery gray-white leaves and lavender, pink, or white flowers with yellow centers in late spring and summer. Native to sandy or rocky soils on coastal bluffs and mountain slopes from southwestern Oregon to Baja California. Usually available as 'Silver Carpet'. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Good along the coast or inland. May be offered as Corethrogyne. Sunset: N/A

Leucadendron species, hybrids, and cultivars (conebush), evergreen shrubs and small trees, most 3-10 feet tall and wide, a few much larger, with lance-shaped, elliptical, or sometimes needlelike leaves and colorful bracts surrounding conical flowerheads that form woody, cone-like seedheads after flowering. Most bloom in winter or spring. Native to South Africa. Sun to part shade, good air circulation, excellent drainage. Sunset: 16-17,20-24

Leucophyllum species and cultivars (Texas ranger), evergreen shrubs, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with felted, silvery gray, gray-green, or green leaves and lightly fragrant, pink or purple, funnel-shaped flowers in late summer and early fall. Native to rocky soils in the Chihuahuan Desert from northeastern Mexico to southern Texas and New Mexico. Full sun, excellent drainage. Best in hot-summer, mild-winter climates and in alkaline soils. Sunset: 7-24

Leucophyta brownii (cushion bush), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with tiny, silvery white, scale-like leaves and small, button-shaped clusters of tiny, pale yellow to creamy white flowers in spring and summer. Native along the south coast of Australia from southwestern Western Australia to the north coast of Tasmania. Sun, fast drainage. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Calocephalus. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Lobelia cardinalis hybrids and cvs. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Lyonothamnus species (ironwood), evergreen tree, 25-50 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, with dark green leaves, paler beneath, and clusters of creamy white flowers in late spring to early summer followed by persistent brown seedpods. Fibrous, reddish gray bark peels to reveal shiny, red underbark. Native to rocky soils on north-facing slopes on the Channel Islands.Usually available as subspecies aspleniifolius, with leaves divided into narrow, notched leaflets. Subspecies floribundus has smooth-edged, undivided leaves. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade inland, excellent drainage. Best near the coast. Sunset: 14-17,19-24

Malosma laurina (laurel sumac), evergreen shrub to small tree, fast growing to 8-20 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with large, lance-shaped, aromatic, green leaves with red margins and large clusters of tiny, fragrant, white flowers in late spring and early summer. Native to sandy or rocky slopes in coastal mountains and valleys from Point Conception and the Channel Islands to Baja California. Sun to part shade, good drainage. May be offered as Rhus. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Malus spp.(edible) e.g''Anna'' (low chill variety for low desert)

plants.culturalInformation: Melica californica (onion grass), cool-season bunchgrass, 1 foot tall and wide, with narrow, bright green leaves and small, airy spring flowers with translucent, papery bracts on 2- to 3-foot stems. Native to the Coast Ranges and Sierra Nevada foothills of central to northern California and southwestern Oregon. Self-sows. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Dormant by mid-summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Mentha spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Monardella villosa (coyote mint), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with aromatic, gray-green to blue-green leaves and spherical clusters of bright lavender or pinkish purple, tubular flowers in late spring to early summer. Native to the Sierra Nevada foothills and Coast Ranges from central California to southern Oregon. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Morella californica (Pacific wax myrtle), evergreen shrub, usually multitrunked, upright to 10-20 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped, glossy, green leaves and inconspicuous flowers and fruits. Native to coastal and inland foothills and valleys from southwestern British Columbia to southern California. Sun along the coast, afternoon shade inland, most soils. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Myrica. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Muhlenbergia rigens (deer grass), warm-season bunchgrass, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with narrow, arching, bright green to gray-green leaves and tall plumes of yellow to purplish flowers followed by airy seedheads in late summer and fall. Native to many habitats from northern California south to Mexico and east to Texas. Self-sows. Sun or light shade, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Good seaside grass. Sunset: 4-24

Myrsine africana (African boxwood), evergreen shrub, 4-8 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with small, aromatic, leathery, dark green leaves, new growth reddish, and inconspicuous yellow flowers. Native to both summer- and winter-rainfall regions of eastern and southern Africa and parts of Asia. Sun to light shade, most soils. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Narcissus species (daffodil), perennials from bulbs with strap-shaped to narrow, almost rush-like leaves and late winter or early spring flowers, singly or in small clusters. Flowers are yellow, white, or some combination of the two with petals surrounding a central trumpet-shaped structure. Native to the western Mediterranean region, especially southwestern Spain and Portugal. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Summer dormant. Need moisture in late winter to bloom well. Sunset: 1-24,A2-A3

Nepeta species (catmint), perennials, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with aromatic, silvery gray-green leaves and upright spikes of lavender-blue flowers in summer. Most are native to the Mediterranean region, from southern Europe and northern Africa to southwestern Asia. N. x faassenii 'Select Blue', 18 inches tall and wide, has darker blue-violet flowers. N. x faassenii 'Six Hills Giant' and N. racemosa 'Walker's Low', both 2-3 feet tall and 4 feet wide, are especially vigorous and long blooming.

Olea europaea (olive), evergreen tree, slow growing to 20-35 feet tall and wide, with gray-green, lance-shaped leaves, silvery beneath, small, white flowers, and oval, green fruits. Native to the Mediterranean region, from southern Europe and northern Africa to southwestern Asia. Fruit drop can be messy and trees can spread invasively. Fruitless cultivars have been developed, but all may produce a few fruits occasionally. 'Majestic Beauty' is said to fruit the least. Full sun, good drainage. Sunset: 8-9,11-24

plants.botanicalName: Ophiopogon planiscapus var. nigrescens SHADE in desert
Opuntia spp. & cvs. (CA natives and non-natives)

plants.culturalInformation: Origanum species and cultivars (oregano), perennials from rhizomes, a few inches to 2 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with small, green to gray-green, often aromatic leaves and clusters of tiny flowers with small bracts or inconspicuous flowers within elongating spikes of large, overlapping bracts. Most are native to mountains of southern Europe, North Africa, and western Asia. May spread by rhizomes or by rooting stems. Sun to part shade, fast-draining soils. Sunset: zones vary

plants.botanicalName: Orthrosanthus var. chimboracensis centroamericanusnow O. monadelphus
Penstemon SW native spp. and cvs.

plants.culturalInformation: Perityle incana (Guadalupe Island rock daisy), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with fine-textured, deeply divided, silvery gray-green leaves and clusters of yellow flowers in spring and summer. Native to rocky coastal cliffs on Guadalupe Island off the coast of northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: N/A

Perovskia species and cultivars (Russian sage), perennials, upright to 2-3 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with oval to oblong, toothed or lobed, sometimes finely dissected, grayish green leaves and lavender to purplish blue, tubular flowers on upright, branched stems in mid- to late summer. Species are native to arid regions of central and southern Asia, from Kazakhstan to northern India and eastern China. Usually available as P. atriplicifolia. Cultivars are either selections of P. atriplicifolia or hybrids with P. abrotanoides and differ mostly in the leaves. Full sun, most well-drained soils. May spread by underground rhizomes. Sunset: 2-24

Phacelia californica, rock phacelia, perennial, 1 foot tall and wide, with velvety, silvery gray-green leaves and purplish pink, funnel-shaped flowers in one-sided, coiled clusters that uncurl as the flowers open in sequence. Self-sows. Important source of nectar for pollinators, especially bees. Native to coastal bluffs and woodland openings in northern California and western Oregon. Sun or part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Phlomis fruticosa (Jerusalem sage), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with felted green to gray-green leaves and whorled clusters of light yellow, tubular, spring and summer flowers at intervals on upright stems. Native to dry, rocky slopes from Crete and Sardinia to western Turkey and Cyprus. Sun to part shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 3B-24

plants.botanicalName: Phlox spp. and cvs. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Pinus mugo (mugo pine), evergreen tree or shrub, variable, usually multitrunked, dense and low branching, 15-20 feet tall and 20-25 feet wide, with dark green to dark grayish green needles. Native to the mountains of central and southern Europe from Spain to the Balkan Peninsula. Usually available as dwarf cultivars, 1-2 feet tall, and mid-sized cultivars, 6-10 feet tall. Sun to light shade, well-drained soil. Best in cool-summer climates. Sunset: 1-11,14-24

Pinus sabiniana (foothill pine), evergreen tree, 40-75 feet tall and 30-50 feet wide, with long, drooping, pale gray-green needles on upturned branches, dark brown, furrowed bark, and large, heavy, brown cones. Native to southwestern Oregon and coastal mountains and Sierra Nevada foothills around the Central Valley in California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Pistacia chinensis (Chinese pistache), deciduous tree, 30-40 feet tall and wide, with compound leaves divided into narrow leaflets and clusters of inconspicuous greenish flowers. Leaves turn brilliant red, orange, or yellow in fall. Native to cool, moist climates of central and western China, Taiwan, and the Philippines. Fruit of female plants can be messy and plants may spread by seed. 'Keith Davey' is a fruitless male selection. Sun, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast or in cool-summer climates. Considered invasive in some parts of California. Sunset: 4-23

plants.botanicalName: Platanus x hispanica and cvs. (Platanus x acerfolia)

plants.culturalInformation: Polypodium californicum (California polypody), fern, 12-18 inches tall and slowly spreading by rhizomes, with bright green fronds arising at intervals. Native to shaded slopes and canyons along the coast and in coastal mountains in northern and central California and in moist locations in southern California and Baja California. Full to part shade, most soils. Deciduous and dormant in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 4-9,14-17,22-24

plants.botanicalName: Prunella spp. (CA native and non-native species)

plants.culturalInformation: Prunus ilicifolia lyonii (Catalina cherry), evergreen shrub, 15-30 feet tall and wide, with glossy, dark green leaves, clusters of small, creamy white flowers in spring, and red to dark purple fruits in fall. Native to the Channel Islands in southern California and the Baja California mainland. Fruit drop can be messy. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as P. lyonii or as P. ilicifolia var. integrifolia. Sunset: 5-9,12-24

plants.botanicalName: Pteris spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Quercus agrifolia (coast live oak), evergreen tree, 35-75 feet tall and 35-50 feet wide, dense and broadly rounded, with leathery, dark green leaves with spiny margins and small, reddish brown acorns. Native along the coast and in the coastal mountains from northern California to northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best in mild climates. Young trees do best in part shade. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Rhaphiolepis indica and cultivars (India hawthorn), evergreen shrubs, 4-5 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with leathery, dark green leaves, new growth often coppery, and clusters of small, star-shaped, lightly fragrant, pink-tinged white flowers in spring. Native to southern China south to Cambodia and Vietnam. 'Ballerina' is 2-3 feet tall and 4 feet wide with deep pink flowers. 'Clara' is 3-5 feet tall and wide with white flowers. 'Springtime' is 5-6 feet tall and wide with pale pink flowers. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Sunset: 8-10,12-24

plants.botanicalName: Rhododendron spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
Rhododendron spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Rhus integrifolia (lemonade berry), evergreen shrub, 3-12 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with leathery, dark green leaves with small, sharp marginal teeth, dense clusters of tiny, pink or white flowers in midwinter to spring, and red, berrylike fruits. Native to dry, open slopes along the coast from Santa Barbara County and the Channel Islands to northern Baja California.Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,14-17,19-24

Ribes sanguineum varieties and cultivars (red-flowering currant), deciduous shrubs, 6-12 feet tall and wide, spreading by rhizomes, with lobed, aromatic, maplelike leaves and small, tubular, red or pink flowers, followed by dark purple berries. Native along the coast and in the Coast Ranges from southern British Columbia to northern California and east to Idaho. 'Inverness White' is a white-flowered selection of the usually pink-flowered variety glutinosum, which may be offered as R. glutinosum. 'King Edward VII' is a red-flowering selection of the variety sanguineum. Part shade to shade, most soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Romneya coulteri (Matilija poppy), perennial from rhizomes, upright to 6-10 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, with bluish gray stems and leaves and large flowers with crinkly, white petals and bright yellow stamens in early summer. Spreads vigorously once established. Native to dry canyons in coastal mountains of southern California and Baja California. Dormant in late summer if grown dry. Full sun, excellent drainage. Can be cut back hard in late fall. Sunset: 4-12,14-24

Rosmarinus officinalis (rosemary), evergreen shrub, prostrate to mounding or upright to 5-6 feet tall, with aromatic, needlelike, dark green leaves and small blue flowers in late winter through spring and often again in fall. Native to coastal cliffs and islands from Spain to Greece and around the northern edge of the Black Sea. Many cultivars. Sun, well-drained soils. Tip prune as needed to maintain form. Sunset: 4-24

plants.botanicalName: Salvia ''Gayle Nielson'' (also Trident as registered trademark name)
Sambucus spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Santolina species (lavender cotton), evergreen shrubs, 1-2 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with narrow, aromatic, dissected and lobed, green or gray leaves and small, rounded flowers in summer. S. chamaecyparissus, with gray leaves and bright yellow flowers, is native to dry, rocky slopes from Portugal to Italy and Croatia. S. rosmarinifolia, with green leaves and pale yellow flowers, is native to Portugal, Spain, and southern France. Full sun, good to excellent drainage. Cut back in late winter or early spring to renew. Plants may need replacing every few years. Sunset: zones vary

plants.botanicalName: Saxifraga spp. (for some CA natives see Micranthes spp.)
Schefflera elegantissima (Dizygotheca elegantissima) (shade in low desert)

plants.culturalInformation: Sisyrinchium bellum and cultivars (blue-eyed grass), perennial, 6-12 inches tall and wide, with narrow, green leaves resembling iris and purplish-blue flowers with yellow centers in spring. Summer dormant. Self-sows. Native to seasonally moist woodlands and grasslands from Oregon to northwestern Baja California. 'Album' has white flowers. 'Greyhound Rock' has pale blue flowers and gray-green leaves. 'Figueroa' has creamy variegation on the leaf margins. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Sphaeralcea spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Sphaeralcea species (globe mallow), perennials, upright to mounding 2-4 feet tall and wide, with softly hairy, shallowly lobed or deeply cut, green or gray-green leaves and bowl-shaped, orange, red, or pale to bright pink flowers. Most are native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. Full sun, fast-draining soils, good air circulation. Cut back in late winter or early spring to renew. Best in hot-summer climates. Sunset: zones vary

plants.botanicalName: Spiraea spp. (CA native and non native spp.)
Stachys maxima (S. maxima and S. minor may be compact selections of S. officinalis)*

plants.culturalInformation: Stipa cernua (nodding needlegrass), cool-season bunchgrass, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with narrow, bluish green leaves and airy, purplish flowers on 2-foot, arching stems in spring. Native to coastal mountains of California and northern Baja California. Self-sows. Dormant or partially dormant in summer. Sun to light shade, good drainage. May be offered as Nassella. Sunset: 7-9,11,14-24

Teucrium fruticans (bush germander), perennial, 4-8 feet tall and wide, with small, aromatic, gray-green leaves on downy, white stems and tiny, lavender-blue flowers in spring or early summer. Native to rocky soils in the Mediterranean region from Portugal to Italy. 'Azureum' is 4-5 feet tall and wide with darker blue flowers. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Sunset: 4-24

plants.botanicalName: Tiarella species & cvs. (CA native and non-native species)

plants.culturalInformation: Trachycarpus fortunei (windmill palm), palm, 20-30 feet tall, with dark green, fan-shaped fronds on 2- to 3-foot stalks, drooping clusters of small, greenish yellow flowers, and dark blue fruit on female plants. Leaves drop and rough, fibrous leaf bases persist on the trunk. Native to mountains of central and southern China. 'Wagnerianus', dwarf Chusan palm, is 12-20 feet tall, with smaller leaves on shorter stalks. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 4-24

Trichostema lanatum (woolly blue curls), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with narrow, glossy, green leaves, woolly and white beneath, and foot-long spikes of blue flowers from woolly, purplish buds in late spring through summer. Native to dry slopes in Coast Ranges of southern California and northern Baja California. Short lived and not always easy in cultivation. Sun to part shade, perfect drainage, no summer water. 'Midnight Magic', a hybrid of T. lanatum and T. purpusii, a species from Mexico, may be more adaptable to garden conditions. Sunset: 14-24

plants.botanicalName: Vaccinium hybrids and cvs (CA native and non- native spp.)
Vachellia farnesiana var. farnsiana (Acacia farnesiana farnesiana)

plants.culturalInformation: Verbena bonariensis (verbena), 2-4 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with narrow, toothed, dark green leaves, widely spaced on upright stems, and rounded clusters of tiny purple flowers from spring to fall. Native to Brazil and Argentina. Self-sows, sometimes aggressively. High risk of invasiveness in California, especially in moist soils. Sunset: 8-24

Vitex agnus-castus (chaste tree), deciduous shrub, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and wide, with grayish green, aromatic leaves divided into oval to lance-shaped leaflets and showy, upright spikes of small, fragrant, lavender-blue or purplish flowers from summer to fall. Native to streambanks and other damp places in southern Europe and western Asia. Self-sows and can be weedy or invasive. Sun, most soils. Sunset: 4-24

Vitis 'Roger's Red' (Roger's Red grape), deciduous vine, fast-growing to 30 feet or more, with large, soft, slightly lobed and serrated leaves that turn brilliant red-orange in fall and small, purple fruit. Climbs by tendrils that attach tightly to nearby shrubs and trees. Hybrid between V. californica and the wine grape V. vinifera. Prune at any time to control spread. Berries are attractive to many birds. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 4-24

Westringia fruticosa hybrids and cultivars (coast rosemary), evergreen shrubs, 4-6 feet tall and 5-10 feet wide, with small, dark gray-green, narrowly linear leaves and small, white flowers almost year-round. Native to sandy soils along the coast in New South Wales, Australia. 'Smokey' and 'Morning Light' have variegated leaves. 'Wynyabbie Gem', a hybrid with W. eremicola, an inland species from southeastern Australia, has lavender flowers. Grey Box (TM) ('WES04'), with gray-green leaves and white flowers, is 3 feet tall and wide. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Good seaside plants. May be offered as W. rosmariniformis. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Yucca rostrata (beaked yucca), succulent rosette, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with stiff, narrow, sharply pointed, silvery gray-blue leaves, slowly forming a thick trunk 10-12 feet tall. Creamy white flowers are borne on a 4-foot stalk in spring or early summer, but rosettes may not flower every year. Native to rocky slopes and ridges in southwestern Texas and northeastern Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 7-24

Yucca schidigera (Mojave yucca), succulent rosette, 3-4 feet tall and wide, with thick, rigid, yellow-green to blue-green, sword-shaped leaves with marginal fibers and a sharp terminal spine. Slowly forms a trunk or several trunks 5-15 feet tall. Creamy white flowers are borne on a 1- to 4-foot stalk in spring or early summer, but rosettes may not flower every year. Native to dry, rocky slopes and flats in southern California and northern Baja California east to New Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 7-16,18-24

plants.botanicalName: Zantedeschia spp. & hybrids SHADE IN DESERT
